What is Juneteenth?
Juneteenth (also known as Freedom Day, Jubilee Day, and Liberation Day) is celebrated annually on the 19th of June in the United States to commemorate Union army general Gordon Granger announcing federal orders in the city of Galveston, Texas, on June 19, 1865, proclaiming that all slaves in Texas were now free. Although the Emancipation Proclamation had formally freed them almost two and a half years earlier and the American Civil War had largely ended with the defeat of the Confederate States in April, Texas was the most remote of the slave states, with a low presence of Union troops, so enforcement of the proclamation had been slow and inconsistent.
Learn more at:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juneteenth
https://www.juneteenth.com/
https://nmaahc.si.edu/blog-post/historical-legacy-juneteenth

Did you know there is an official flag for Juneteenth?
Learn more about the flag:
https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/19/us/freedom-day-juneteenth-flag-meaning-trnd/index.html

Warm regards,
Melinda DiMaio

Following graduation from FDR, Catherine plans to attend Indiana University to study secondary education.

post_text: Congratulations to FDR Senior Michelle Castellanos, who has earned the New York State Seal of Biliteracy. The New York State Seal of Biliteracy (NYSSB) recognizes high school graduates who have attained a high level of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing in one or more languages, in addition to English. The intent of the NYSSB is to encourage the study of languages; identify high school graduates with language and biliteracy skills for employers; provide universities with additional information about applicants seeking admission; prepare students with twenty-first century skills; recognize the value of foreign and native language instruction in schools; and affirm the value of diversity in a multilingual society.

post_text: Congratulations to FDR Junior Sarah Trainor, who now holds the NATIONAL RECORD in the Steeplechase! Furthermore, the International Association of Athletics Federation (IAFF) recognized Sarah's time as the FASTEST IN THE WORLD for any U20 athlete (athlete under the age of 20) and the 2nd FASTEST IN THE WORLD for any athlete of any age in this event. Congratulations one more time on this remarkable achievement Sarah!
